utterances: Juma only began working with college students a few years ago, so it's too early to know its success rate.
Chavez meets weekly with about 25 students, either in person, on Skype, or on the phone.
She's also taking on new students like Taylor Lott, a high school senior who's going to the University of Southern California next year.
Taylor and her mother, Cassie Hoskins, recently came to Chavez's office with a lot of questions about financial aid.
So I was kind of confused because I was worried, like - more loans.
I can't do that.
I'm not sure, you know, how that would work.
Why would she need loans if she had financial aid?
And, you know, I...
Chavez tells them they could take out a small subsidized loan.
If you're going to be borrowing more than, say, $5,000 a year, at that point we really start looking at it as somewhat unmanageable debt.
Chavez's coaching is rooted in practical dilemmas, but Taylor's mom, Cassie, says it can also be inspirational.
She started to just blossom.
She exploded.
She was able to speak before people, and she was able to express herself - the things that she wanted in life.
She was able to express her aspirations for college.
Do you feel you have a definition of success for your new job?
Fitzgerald says the hoopla surrounding Francis' statements can distort what he's actually trying to say.
Stamp.
I think, at this point, the federal government would need to step in.
Fannie and Freddie, they either own or insure about one half of the mortgages in the U.S.
There are big problems with credits slowing the mortgage markets right now, and Fannie and Freddie are really pretty much the only game in town there.
So I think the feds are concerned, if something happened, and Fannie and Freddie fail, then we'd see a much more severe downturn in the housing market.
And one advantage, perhaps, in the federal government taking over Fannie and Freddie is that it could bring down mortgage rates a bit.

If you look at the spread between the interest rates that Fannie and Freddie are paying versus risk-free treasuries, that spread has widened a bit, which indicates that people are, perhaps, a bit reluctant to lend to Fannie and Freddie despite the rescue package that the federal government put together last month.

So, if the feds take it over, and the Treasury Department is essentially running them, then that would allow Fannie and Freddie to borrow at lower rates, and that could bring down mortgage rates for home borrowers.
So, as dark as the clouds are now, there might be silver lining for future homebuyers?
I think that that's the case.
There could be some advantages.
And then, over the longer run, we need to think about what our mortgage policy should be, how involved the federal government should be in the market.
But I think that's a decision for the next president.
Gus, I know this is asking a very big question, but when do you possibly see the banks being able to pull out of this crisis?
Well, it's going to take some time.
I mean, there are a lot of excesses that were developed over the past few years.
Too many homes were built.
There were people who, in retrospect, who got mortgages who probably shouldn't have.
And so it's taking some time for all this to fall out.
Inventories are going to need to decline further, so we have builders cutting back.
You know, they're building fewer homes, and we saw that again today.
At some point, we see prices falling, which will make prices affordable for some folks.
So, you know, we probably don't think conditions are going to stabilize until some time in the first half of next year.
I have to say, for someone who's saying the conditions aren't going to stabilize until sometime next year, you sound relatively calm.
I think, for the average Joe, you keep hearing these stories, and it's hard not to panic.
Why shouldn't we panicking?
Well, I think, for most homeowners, as long as you didn't buy in the past few years, you're probably in OK shape.
It could be that the value of your house has gone down, but it's probably still worth more than you paid for it.
You probably are able to afford your mortgage payments.
So those folks are doing OK.
I mean, obviously, it's not good if the value of your house declines, but at the same point, they're not facing severe financial distress.
I think there are people who have purchased their home more recently or perhaps refinanced, maybe they faced a higher interest rate because they had an adjustable-rate mortgage.
Maybe they qualified for a loan that, in retrospect, they probably shouldn't have gotten.
So there are some people who are facing some severe problems, but I think, for the majority of homeowners, they're not in immediate danger.
That's Gus Fauchet.
He's the director of microeconomics for Moody's economy.com.
You know, we just heard about the potential silver lining for future home buyers.
If you are a first time buyer, things may be looking even brighter thanks to a new tax credit.
Later on in the program, our personal finance contributor Michelle Singletary fills us in on how it works.
That's coming up when NPR's Day to Day continues.
President George W.

Bush's book of portraits of more than 60 soldiers, sailors, airmen and Marines who served in wars under his watch was published this week - ""Portraits Of Courage: A Commander In Chief's Tribute to America's Warriors."" President Bush has done a number of interviews in recent days talking about how he took up painting after leaving office and how he came to paint portraits of men and women that he sent in to war.
We're joined by one of the president's subjects now.
They call each other friends.
Michael Rodriguez was a U.S.
Army Special Forces Green Beret who served from 1992 to 2013 in Latin America, Somalia, Haiti, two tours in Afghanistan, nine deployments in 21 years.
Michael Rodriguez joins us now from his home near Fort Bragg, N.C.
Thanks so much for being with us.
Oh, thank you for having me.
What do you think of your portrait?
Oh, wow.
I'm, you know, I'm blown away that my former commander in chief would actually take the time to paint those that served under him.
And I'm humbled that he selected me as one of them.
I think it's a pretty good representation of me.
I couldn't - I'm still kind of processing the whole thing.
Well, it shows a man with a very strong face, very vivid lines, dark hair.
Do you have two eyes that are of different color?
Yes, sir.

So the story behind the colors of my eyes being different is I actually wear prosthetic lenses to help correct some of the neurological vision issues that I have, which are secondary to the number of brain injuries that I received in my service.
You suffered how many concussions, Rod?
Probably in the neighborhood of about 12 that I can remember, like 12 significant ones.
But, you know, through training and through a lot of deployments, you know, I'd probably had a few more than that when I was finally hospitalized for them.
You know, when I sat down with the doctors, they were like, all right, let's figure this out.
And I was like, I had never really taken a count of it.
It's not like I was keeping score.
All of that be noted, was it hard to stop being a Green Beret?
One is to recognize that the Smithsonian needs to be better positioned to serve its 21st-century audiences.

I also think it's crucially important that, if the Smithsonian really is to be of value, then it's also got to be a place that is willing to wrestle with contemporary concerns, to contextualize - whether it's science or the arts or history - to help people think about how do we help understand questions around race, around environmentalism, globalization?
Do you mean to say you want to be giving a historical perspective on the news?
Just like any college student, Taylor Lott and Jose Diaz will become more and more independent as they navigate life on their own.
But unlike their classmates whose parents went to college, their experiences will, in some way, separate them from their families.
Over Skype, Diaz paints a clear picture of what his life would be like without his coach's help.
Worst case would have been that I'd be forced to move back to Mexico and watch over the land that my family owns down there.

Coaching ventures like Juma are designed to guide students through college to their new lives beyond, with the eventual goal of preparing them for a time when they won't have coaches and won't need them.
For NPR News, I'm Claire Trageser in San Diego.
This is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED from NPR News.
